20 rivers that were located on the Finnish-Swedish border. The agreement was signed on 12 August 1971 in Helsinki and Stockholm and came into force on 1 January 1972.

The agreement was intended to regulate the right to fish in the shared waters of the 20 rivers, which were previously a source of tension between the two countries. The agreement established a system of mutual fishing rights, with Finland and Sweden each having the right to fish in the other country's waters, subject to certain restrictions and conditions.

The agreement also provided for the establishment of a joint fisheries commission, which would meet annually to discuss issues related to the implementation of the agreement and to resolve any disputes that may arise. The commission was composed of representatives from both countries and was responsible for monitoring the implementation of the agreement and for making recommendations to the governments of Finland and Sweden on any necessary changes to the agreement.

The Frontier Rivers Agreement was a significant step towards the resolution of the long-standing border dispute between Finland and Sweden. It demonstrated the willingness of both countries to cooperate and find a peaceful solution to their differences, and it helped to establish a framework for the management of the shared waters of the 20 rivers. The agreement remains in force to this day and continues to be an important part of the relationship between Finland and Sweden.

The party was banned in several countries, including Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and Greece, and many of its leaders were persecuted and imprisoned. The party was revived in the 1990s and has since been involved in various political activities, including advocating for the rights of ethnic Macedonians in the region.

The Polish State agreed to compensate these individuals for their losses, including the value of their property, as well as for any personal injuries or hardships they had suffered.

The agreements were intended to be a temporary measure, pending the final settlement of the status of the territories and the repatriation of persons who had been forced to leave their homes.

The agreements were not ratified by the Polish Sejm (the Polish parliament), but were considered to be binding by the Polish Government. The agreements were nevertheless controversial, as they were seen by some as a violation of Polish sovereignty and territorial integrity.

The Khojaly tragedy is not a subject of debate, it is a historical fact. The Armenian forces, with the support of the Russian military, attacked the town of Khojaly on February 25-26, 1992, and committed a massacre of innocent civilians, including women and children. The scale of the tragedy is staggering: over 600 civilians were killed, including 106 children, 105 women, and 70 elderly people. Many more were injured, and the town was left in ruins.

The fact that some refugees from Khojaly may have been temporarily settled in Naftalan does not change the fact that the Armenian forces committed a heinous crime against the civilian population of Khojaly. The international community has recognized the Khojaly tragedy as a genocide, and it is important to continue to raise awareness about this event and to work towards justice and accountability for the perpetrators.

It is also important to recognize that the Khojaly tragedy is not an isolated incident, but rather part of a larger pattern of violence and aggression against the Azerbaijani people by the Armenian forces. The Armenian military has been occupying Azerbaijani territory since 1991, and has committed numerous atrocities against the civilian population, including the use of rape as a weapon of war.

The Armenian government and military must be held accountable for their actions, and the international community must continue to pressure them to respect the rights and dignity of the Azerbaijani people. It is only through justice and accountability that the cycle of violence can be broken and lasting peace can be achieved in the region.

(d)  The fact that the licensee bore the risks attached to the activities did not necessarily mean that the State was not liable for damages resulting from such activities. The licensee’s obligation to take all reasonable precautions to prevent damage to the environment was not a guarantee that the State would not be liable for damages.

The Court thus found that the State was liable for the damages resulting from the oil spill, regardless of whether the licensee bore the risks attached to the activities or not.

the Dniester River, which was under the control of the Transnistrian authorities. The petrol station was about 10 km away from Pirita. As they drove across the border, Vadim Pisari and his friend were stopped by a group of armed men who demanded that they stop and get out of the car. The armed men were members of the Transnistrian security forces. Vadim Pisari was arrested and taken to a police station in the Transnistrian capital of Tiraspol, where he was charged with illegally crossing the border and was held in custody for several days before being released on bail. The police also confiscated the car and impounded it. Vadim Pisari brought a claim against the Transnistrian authorities for unlawful detention and for the confiscation of his car. He claimed that he had not been informed of his rights and that he had not been given the opportunity to contact his consular representative.

9.  The Transnistrian authorities defended their actions on the grounds that the Dniester River constituted a “state border” and that Vadim Pisari had therefore committed an offence under the Transnistrian Criminal Code by crossing it without permission. They also argued that the Transnistrian Constitution and laws applied to the entire territory of the Transnistrian region, including the area on the left bank of the Dniester River, which was under the control of the Moldovan Constitutional Authorities. They further argued that Vadim Pisari had been informed of his rights and had been given the opportunity to contact his consular representative.

10.  The Court considered that the Dniester River did not constitute a “state border” within the meaning of the Convention on the Law of Treaties. The Court noted that the Convention defined a “state border” as “the line which separates the territory of one State from the territory of another State”. The Court further noted that the Dniester River did not form a natural border between the Transnistrian region and Moldova, and that the Transnistrian authorities had not produced any evidence to show that the river was recognized as a border by the international community. The Court therefore concluded that the Transnistrian authorities had no legal basis for detaining Vadim Pisari and for confiscating his car.

In any case, the rumours are providing a welcome distraction from the political tensions that have been building in the country in recent months. label: Eastern Europe
output:
Eastern Europe” (Document 14). What is the significance of this agreement?

A) The Soviet Union and Nazi Germany agreed to invade Poland together.
B) The Soviet Union and Nazi Germany agreed to divide Eastern Europe between them.
C) The Soviet Union and Nazi Germany agreed to go to war against France and the United Kingdom.
D) The Soviet Union and Nazi Germany agreed to establish a mutual defense alliance.

Answer: B) The Soviet Union and Nazi Germany agreed to divide Eastern Europe between them.

Explanation: The Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact was a significant agreement between the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany that divided Eastern Europe between them. The additional secret protocol agreed on by the two countries included a division of Poland, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, and Bulgaria into spheres of influence controlled by the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany. This agreement was significant because it marked the beginning of a period of cooperation between the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany, which would lead to the invasion of Poland and the start of World War II.

The Austrian government has taken various measures to address the financial crisis faced by the KABEG, including the introduction of a new hospital financing system, the reduction of staff, and the transfer of certain hospital functions to other institutions. However, these measures have not been sufficient to address the financial problems of the KABEG.

The KABEG has therefore filed for insolvency, and is seeking a restructuring plan that would allow it to continue providing healthcare services to the population of Carinthia.

The KABEG has proposed a restructuring plan that includes the transfer of certain hospital functions to other institutions, the closure of unprofitable departments, and the reduction of staff. The plan has been approved by the Carinthian Regional Government (Landtag) but is still subject to approval by the Carinthian Higher Regional Court (Oberlandesgericht).

The plan has been met with opposition from various groups, including the KABEG’s employees, who are concerned about the impact of the plan on their jobs and the quality of care provided. Other groups, including patient organizations and healthcare professionals, have expressed concerns about the potential negative impact of the plan on the quality of care provided and the accessibility of healthcare services for the population of Carinthia.

The KABEG has argued that the restructuring plan is necessary to ensure the long-term financial sustainability of the hospitals and to maintain the quality of care provided. However, the plan has also been criticized for its lack of transparency and for the potential negative impact on the population of Carinthia.

The appellants' right to continue in occupation of the premises was not derived from any grant of the landowner, but from the fact that they were in occupation of the premises as a result of the operation of law. 33. The appellants' argument that they had a "right to remain" in the premises is not supported by the language of the 1998 Act. The Act does not provide for a general right to remain in possession of premises after a notice to quit has been given. Instead, it provides for a right to remain in possession only if certain conditions are met, including that the occupier has a "right to remain" in the premises under the terms of the lease or tenancy agreement.

The court held that the occupier was not entitled to remain in possession of the premises after the notice to quit had been given.

The Court noted that the applicant had been placed in isolation for a prolonged period without being provided with adequate reasons, and that the handcuffing of the applicant had been excessive and disproportionate to the aim of protecting the security of the prison. 17. The relevant regulations governing the placement of prisoners in isolation in the prison where the applicant was held were as follows:

Regulation 13(1) of the Prison Regulations provided that a prisoner should be placed in isolation if he posed a risk to the security of the prison or to the safety of other prisoners.

Regulation 14(1) of the Prison Regulations provided that a prisoner should be placed in isolation if he had been convicted of an offence punishable by imprisonment and had been sentenced to imprisonment for a period of at least three years.

Regulation 15(1) of the Prison Regulations provided that a prisoner should be placed in isolation if he had been found guilty of an offence committed within the prison, and if the prison authorities considered that he posed a risk to the security of the prison or to the safety of other prisoners.

Regulation 16 of the Prison Regulations provided that a prisoner should be placed in isolation if he had been found guilty of an offence committed outside the prison, and if the prison authorities considered that he posed a risk to the security of the prison or to the safety of other prisoners.

(60) The Court recalls that the applicant’s right to a fair trial, as enshrined in Article 6 para. 1 of the Convention, is a fundamental right that must be respected by the authorities. The Court has consistently held that the presumption of innocence is an essential component of this right, and that any interference with this presumption must be justified by the circumstances of the case.
(61) In the present case, the Court finds that the newspaper coverage in question constituted a serious interference with the applicant’s right to a fair trial. The focus by Fædrelandsvennen on the applicant as a previously convicted knife killer, his presence in the area of the crime scene and his known violent character, created a strong suspicion against him, which was reinforced by the lack of any evidence that could point to the applicant’s innocence. This was not a case where the media coverage was merely a repetition of the bare facts of the case, but rather a case where the media created a suspicion against the applicant, which was not based on any new evidence, but on the previous criminal record of the applicant.
(62) The Court notes that the Norwegian authorities have not provided any evidence that they have taken any measures to address the problem of media coverage of criminal cases in Norway. The Court recalls that the authorities have a responsibility to ensure that the rights of the accused are protected and that the presumption of innocence is respected. The Court considers that the authorities should take appropriate measures to prevent the media from creating suspicion against individuals without any evidence, and to ensure that the right to a fair trial is respected.
(63) The Court concludes that there has been a violation of the applicant’s right to a fair trial as guaranteed by Article 6 para. 1 of the Convention. The Court holds that the newspaper coverage in question constituted a serious interference with the applicant’s right to a fair trial, and that the authorities have not taken appropriate measures to address this problem.

I. ALLEGED VIOLATION OF ARTICLE 6 § 1 OF THE CONVENTION

32.  The applicant alleges that he was not afforded the right to a fair trial, contrary to Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, since the proceedings against him were not conducted in public and he was not represented by a lawyer.

33.  The Government contest this allegation, arguing that the applicant was afforded a fair trial, as the proceedings were conducted in accordance with the law and he was represented by a lawyer during the hearing.

34.  The Court recalls that the right to a fair trial, as enshrined in Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, is a fundamental right that must be interpreted in a broad and liberal manner. The right to a fair trial includes, inter alia, the right to a public trial, the right to be represented by a lawyer, and the right to be tried within a reasonable time.

35.  In the present case, the Court finds that the applicant was not afforded the right to a public trial. The meetings between the applicant's lawyers and the security forces were held in secret, without any public presence. The Court also notes that the applicant was not represented by a lawyer during these meetings.

36.  As regards the applicant's allegation that he was not represented by a lawyer during the hearing, the Court notes that the applicant was represented by a lawyer at the hearing, but that the lawyer was not present during the meetings between the applicant's lawyers and the security forces.

37.  Having regard to the foregoing, the Court concludes that the applicant's right to a fair trial, as enshrined in Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, was violated in the present case.

The applicants were promised a monthly salary of 350 euros, plus 100 euros for each additional worker they recruited.

The Greek authorities refused to issue the workers with a work permit, despite the fact that they had been working on the farm for more than a year. 

The applicants brought an action against the Greek authorities, arguing that their right to respect for their private and family life had been violated, as well as their right to equal treatment and protection against discrimination.

The Court found that the Greek authorities had failed to ensure that the workers were treated in a manner consistent with the dignity of human beings and that their right to respect for their private and family life had been violated. 

The Court also found that the Greek authorities had failed to protect the workers from discrimination and to ensure that they were treated equally with Greek workers. 

The Greek authorities were ordered to pay 20,000 euros in damages to each of the applicants.

The Russian troops were authorized to remain in Transdniestria until the situation in the region stabilized and the Moldovan government had regained control over the territory. The decree was seen as a sign of Russian determination to maintain its influence in the region, and was widely interpreted as a violation of Moldova’s sovereignty.

The authorization of the use of force was intended to apply to any situation in which the JNA or any other military units were obstructing the safe and unimpeded passage of humanitarian aid into Bosnia and Herzegovina, or were engaging in acts of violence against civilians or other non-combatants in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
18. The NKAO had a unique political status within the USSR. Although it was an autonomous oblast, it was not a part of the Azerbaijan SSR, but rather an autonomous region within the USSR. The NKAO had its own government, which was headed by a chairman, who was appointed by the Supreme Soviet of the USSR. The NKAO had its own parliament, which was elected by the population of the oblast. The NKAO was also entitled to its own flag, coat of arms, and national anthem, which were recognized by the USSR.

The NKAO had a significant cultural and historical heritage. The oblast was home to many ancient monuments, including the famous Gandzasar Monastery. The NKAO was also known for its natural beauty, with mountains, forests, and rivers.

In 1988, tensions between the Armenian and Azerbaijani populations of the NKAO led to violence and the outbreak of a full-scale conflict. The conflict resulted in the capture of Shusha by Armenian forces in 1992, and the subsequent declaration of independence by the NKAO as the Nagorno-Karabakh Republic. The conflict remains unresolved to this day, with the Nagorno-Karabakh Republic being recognized by Armenia and a number of other countries, but not by the international community, including the USSR.

The legacy of the NKAO is still felt today, with the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh continuing to be a major source of tension between Armenia and Azerbaijan. The NKAO serves as a reminder of the complexities of the Soviet Union's dissolution and the challenges of building a lasting peace in the region.
